body: Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.

This is a first pass at adding a C++ API for Cronet. I still haven't figured out how testing should work.

Hi - the makefile is not updated directly but it is generated. Adding @nicolasnoble to advise on how to get this functionality checked in, and adding @yang-g for reviewing the API.
I did generate the Makefile using "./tools/buildgen/generate_projects.sh". It's possible that I used it script incorrectly though. Let me see see what happened.

this is ok to test

It looks to me like the Makefile changes were properly generated from the build.yaml changes. We'll have to see the test output to be sure, but I think that part is OK.

BTW, I tried running the tests locally as specified by the [contributing documentation](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md), but it didn't seem to work.

gcasto@gcasto-2:~/grpc$ ./tools/run_tests/run_tests.py 
languages with custom make options cannot be built simultaneously with other languages

I could run tests for a specific language using the "-l" flag, but I couldn't run the entire suite. Is this expected?
It looks like this change would only affect the C++ target, so you should only need to run the C++ tests to verify it.

So, it looks like the tests are failing, but I don't think that this should be related to my change. This shouldn't even change the compilation on Window for example. Should I do something to re-run the tests?
LGTM

We found a Contributor License Agreement for you (the sender of this pull request) and all commit authors, but as best as we can tell these commits were authored by someone else.  If that's the case,  please add them to this pull request and have them confirm that they're okay with these commits being contributed to Google.  If we're mistaken and you did author these commits, just reply here to confirm.

<!-- need_author_consent -->

CLAs look good, thanks!

<!-- ok -->
What's the next step here? It looks like I still need approval.
jenkins: test this please
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.
Are these flakes in the tests? These don't seem related to my change (it shouldn't even have touched the Windows).
@nicolasnoble @jtattermusch - Could you please look at the failures? They indeed seem unrelated.

@makdharma   no point for me too look at the tests when one of the most important suites "Basic Tests Linux" didn't finish running (it probably got stuck for issues associated with worker reboots, so you'll need to restart the tests).
Please rebase to get a fresh test run and then we can look at the results.
Looks like the tests are still failing.
Ping?
